{{short description|American country music duo}} {{Use mdy dates|date=June 2012}} {{Infobox musical artist | name = Louvin Brothers | image = Louvin Brothers.jpg | caption = Charlie (left) and Ira Louvin | image_size = | background = group_or_band | alias = | origin = [[Henagar, Alabama]], US | genre = {{Flatlist| * [[Country music|Country]] * [[Bluegrass music|bluegrass]] * [[Gospel music|gospel]] }} | years_active = 1940–1963 | label = [[Capitol Records|Capitol]] | associated_acts = | website = | current_members = [[Ira Louvin]]
[[Charlie Louvin]] }} '''The Louvin Brothers''' were an American musical duo composed of brothers [[Ira Louvin|Ira]] and [[Charlie Louvin]] (''né'' Loudermilk). The brothers are cousins to [[John D. Loudermilk]], a [[Nashville Songwriters Hall of Fame]] member. The brothers wrote and performed [[country music|country]], [[Bluegrass music|bluegrass]], and [[gospel music]]. Ira played [[mandolin]] and generally sang lead vocal in the [[tenor]] range, while Charlie played [[rhythm guitar]] and offered supporting vocals in a lower pitch. They helped popularize the vocal technique of [[close harmony]] in country and country-rock.{{cite web|last=Johnson|first=Jon|title=Livin' Lovin' Losin' the Louvin's Way|publisher=Country Standard Time|date=October 2003|url=http://www.countrystandardtime.com/d/article.asp?xid=943|access-date=January 22, 2010}} After becoming regulars at the [[Grand Ole Opry]] and scoring a string of hit singles in the late 1950s and early '60s, the Louvin Brothers broke up in 1963 due in large part to Charlie growing tired of Ira's addictions and reckless behavior. Ira died in a traffic accident in 1965. They were inducted into the [[Country Music Hall of Fame]] in 2001, and Charlie died of cancer in 2011. ''[[Rolling Stone]]'' ranked the Louvin Brothers number four on its list of the 20 Greatest Duos of All Time.{{Cite magazine|date=2015-12-17|title=20 Greatest Duos of All Time|url=https://www.rollingstone.com/music/music-lists/20-greatest-duos-of-all-time-16272/4-the-louvin-brothers-67876/|access-date=2020-09-06|magazine=Rolling Stone|language=en-US}} ==Background== Brothers [[Ira Louvin|Ira]] (April 21, 1924 – June 20, 1965) and [[Charlie Louvin|Charlie]] (July 7, 1927 – January 26, 2011) Louvin (''né'' Loudermilk) adopted the name Louvin Brothers in the 1940s as they began their career in gospel music. They grew up listening to and singing [[shape note]] music, which influenced the rest of their musical output.{{Cite web |title=Cordelia's Dad Interviewed by Auger/Anvil |url=http://cordeliasdad.com/antiqueSite/anvilinter.html |access-date=2024-07-24 |website=cordeliasdad.com}} Their first foray into secular music was the minor hit "The Get Acquainted Waltz", recorded with [[Chet Atkins]]. Their other hits include "Cash on the Barrelhead" and "When I Stop Dreaming". They joined the Grand Ole Opry in 1955 and stayed there until breaking up in 1963.{{cite book| last = Wolfe| first = Charles K.| title = In Close Harmony: The Story of the Louvin Brothers| publisher = Univ. Press of Mississippi| year = 1996| url = https://archive.org/details/incloseharmonyst00char | url-access = registration| page = [https://archive.org/details/incloseharmonyst00char/page/91 91]| isbn = 0-87805-892-3}} Their songs were heavily influenced by their [[Baptist]] faith and warned against sin.{{citation needed|date=January 2012}} Nevertheless, Ira Louvin was notorious for his drinking, womanizing, and volcanic temper. He was married four times; his third wife Faye shot him four times in the chest and twice in the hand after he allegedly tried to strangle her with a telephone cord.{{cite news|title='Opry' Singer Star Shot; Wife Jailed|newspaper=The Miami Herald|date=February 21, 1963|url=https://news.google.com/newspapers?id=WqAyAAAAIBAJ&dq=ira-louvin%20wife&pg=962%2C1956387|access-date=March 27, 2011}} Although seriously injured, he survived. When performing and drinking, Ira would sometimes become angry enough on stage to smash his mandolin when he was unable to tune it, and - when sober - glue it back together. His style was heavily influenced by [[Bill Monroe]], and his brother [[Charlie Monroe]], who had a tempestuous relationship with Ira, considered him one of the top mandolin players in Nashville.{{cite book|last=Louvin|first=Charlie|title=Satan Is Real|year=2012}} In his [[The New York Times|''New York Times'']] review of Charlie's biography ''Satan Is Real'', Alex Abramovich said, "Ira Louvin was a full head taller than his younger brother, played the mandolin like Bill Monroe, and sang in an impossibly high, tense, quivering tenor. Charlie strummed a guitar, grinned like a [[vaudevillian]], and handled the bottom register. But every so often, in the middle of a song, some hidden signal flashed and the brothers switched places — with Ira swooping down from the heights, and Charlie angling upward — and even the most careful listeners would lose track of which man was carrying the lead. This was more than close-harmony singing; each instance was an act of [[transubstantiation]]."{{cite news| url=https://www.nytimes.com/2012/02/19/books/review/satan-is-real-the-story-of-the-louvin-brothers.html | work=The New York Times | first=Alex | last=Abramovich | title='Satan Is Real,' the Story of the Louvin Brothers | date=February 17, 2012}} In 1963, fed up with Ira's drinking and abusive behavior, Charlie started a solo career, and Ira also went on his own. Ira died on June 20, 1965, at the age of 41. His fourth wife, Anne Young, and he were on the way home from a performance in [[Kansas City]] when they came to a section of construction on Highway 70 outside of [[Williamsburg, Missouri]], where traffic had been reduced down to one lane. A drunken driver struck their car head-on, and both Ira and Anne were killed instantly.{{cite news | last = Strauss| first = Neil | title = The Pop Life| newspaper = New York Times| date = November 28, 1996| url = https://www.nytimes.com/1996/11/28/arts/the-pop-life-500887.html?pagewanted=1| access-date = January 22, 2010}} At the time, a warrant for Ira's arrest had been issued on a [[DUI]] charge. Charlie died of [[pancreatic cancer]] on January 26, 2011, at age 83. ==Legacy== Country-rock band [[The Byrds]] recorded the Louvin-penned "The Christian Life" for their 1968 release ''[[Sweetheart of the Rodeo]]''. [[Emmylou Harris]] had a hit with the brothers' tune "[[If I Could Only Win Your Love]]" in 1975. Her cover version reached number four on the [[Billboard Hot Country Singles & Tracks|''Billboard ''Hot Country Singles]] chart and earned the top spot on the RPM Country Tracks chart in Canada.{{cite web |title=Music Friday: Emmylou Harris Would 'Proudly Wear Your Wedding Ring' If She Could Only Win Your Love |url=https://thejewelerblog.wordpress.com/2017/08/03/music-friday-emmylou-harris-would-proudly-wear-your-wedding-ring-if-she-could-only-win-your-love/ |website=The Jeweler Blog |date=August 3, 2017 |access-date=21 September 2019}} In 2001, the Louvin Brothers were inducted into the [[Country Music Hall of Fame]].[http://www.countrymusichalloffame.org/full-list-of-inductees/view/the-louvin-brothers- Country Music Hall of Fame entry for The Louvin Brothers.] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20110130051332/http://countrymusichalloffame.org/full-list-of-inductees/view/the-louvin-brothers- |date=January 30, 2011 }} Retrieved January 21, 2010. The tribute CD ''[[Livin', Lovin', Losin': Songs of the Louvin Brothers]]'', produced by [[Carl Jackson]] and Kathy Louvin and released in 2003, won the 2004 [[Grammy Award]] for Best Country Album. ===''Satan Is Real'' album=== {{Main|Satan Is Real}} [[Image:Louvin.jpg|thumb|alt=Satan is Real album cover|''[[Satan Is Real]] album cover'']] Although the brothers are still remembered today for their musical talent, they are also remembered for the unusual cover used for their 1959 album, ''Satan Is Real''. Designed by Ira Louvin, the cover features the brothers standing in a rock [[quarry]] in front of a {{convert|12|ft|m|adj=mid|-tall}} plywood rendition of the [[Devil]] as several hidden tires soaked in kerosene burn behind them as fire and brimstone.{{cite web|last=Stein |first=Lorin |url=http://killingthebuddha.com/mag/exegesis/satan-is-real/ |title=KtB – Satan Is Real |publisher=Killingthebuddha.com |date=2006-06-06 |access-date=2012-06-24}} Some reviewers count this as being one of the "greatest iconic album covers of all time."{{cite web|url=http://www.aquariumdrunkard.com/2006/12/13/the-louvin-brothers-satan-is-real/ |title=MP3 Blog, Music Blog » The Louvin Brothers :: Satan Is Real |publisher=Aquarium Drunkard |date=2006-12-13 |access-date=2012-06-24}} The opening bars of the album's title track "Satan Is Real" can be heard at the beginning of [[Hank Williams III]]'s "Medley: Straight to Hell / Satan Is Real", on his ''[[Straight to Hell (album)|Straight to Hell]]'' album of 2006. It is also excerpted in [[Will Ferrell]]'s 2009 one-man Broadway show, ''[[You're Welcome America|You're Welcome America.
